    Discovery of a Vitamin D Receptor-Silent Vitamin D Derivative That Impairs Sterol Regulatory Element-Binding Protein In Vivo

    • Fumihiro Kawagoe
      Fumihiro Kawagoe
      Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Teikyo University, 2-11-1 Kaga, Itabashi-ku, Tokyo 173-8605, Japan

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Vitamin D3 metabolites inhibit the expression of lipogenic genes by impairing sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP), a master transcription factor of lipogenesis, independent of their canonical activity through a vitamin D receptor (VDR). Herein, we designed and synthesized a series of vitamin D derivatives to search for a drug-like small molecule that suppresses the SREBP-induced lipogenesis without affecting the VDR-controlled calcium homeostasis in vivo. Evaluation of the derivatives in cultured cells and mice led to the discovery of VDR-silent SREBP inhibitors and to the development of KK-052 (50), the first vitamin D-based SREBP inhibitor that has been demonstrated to mitigate hepatic lipid accumulation without calcemic action in mice. KK-052 maintained the ability of 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 to induce the degradation of SREBP but lacked in the VDR-mediated activity. KK-052 serves as a valuable compound for interrogating SREBP/SCAP in vivo and may represent an unprecedented translational opportunity of synthetic vitamin D analogues.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The fundamental actions of vitamin D3 and its metabolites are to maintain calcium and phosphorus homeostasis in animals. The activity is achieved by the direct binding of 1α,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 [1α,25(OH)2D3], a hydroxylated metabolite of vitamin D3, to the vitamin D receptor (VDR).(1,2) VDR is a vitamin D-specific member of the nuclear receptor family of transcription factors that control expression of a myriad of genes involved in calcium/phosphorus homeostasis,(3) cell differentiation and growth,(4) and immune responses.(5−7) The biological importance of VDR and the existence of 1α,25(OH)2D3 as a potent lead agonist have rendered VDR an attractive target for pharmaceutical development. Several thousands of vitamin D analogues have chemically been synthesized, and eight synthetic VDR ligands have achieved clinical uses: for example, calcipotriol(8) for psoriasis, paricalcitol(9) for secondary hyperparathyroidism, and eldecalcitol(10) for osteoporosis. The majority of the synthetic vitamin D analogues contain modified side chains on the CD ring or substitution of the functional groups on the A-ring, but usually maintain three hydroxy groups or their equivalents at C1, C3, and C25 positions that are required for the interaction with VDR.(11) Recently, introduction of a large substituent at the CD-ring side chain afforded a VDR-antagonist or partial agonist,(12−17) and truncation of the side chain led to the discovery of an in vivo active VDR ligand that lacked in calcemic action.(18) However, the synthetic efforts of vitamin D analogues have long been centered for VDR as a pharmacological target.
    Another genomic target of vitamin D3 has recently emerged. We previously reported that 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 [25(OH)D3, 1, Figure 1], a major circulating form of vitamin D3, inhibits the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding proteins (SREBPs), a family of master transcription factor for lipogenesis, by interacting with SREBP cleavage-activating protein (SCAP), a specific escort protein for SREBP.(19−21) The association of 25(OH)D3 with SCAP induces degradation of both SCAP and SREBP to block the expression of SREBP-controlled lipogenic genes.(21) Importantly, the SREBP effects of vitamin D appear to be independent of VDR. Among the vitamin D metabolites, 25(OH)D3 is the most potent SREBP inhibitor, and 25(OH)D3-treated cells exhibited a higher degree of SREBP degradation than cells treated with 1α,25(OH)2D3, a potent VDR agonist. In line with this, siRNA knockdown of VDR failed to rescue the 25(OH)D3-induced degradation.(21) A low μM dose of 25(OH)D3 inhibits cellular lipogenesis by limiting the expression of SREBP-responsive genes in cultured cells, suggesting that 25(OH)D3 serves as a starting point of designing SREBP inhibitors.
    Although no small-molecule inhibitors of SREBP/SCAP have been approved for clinical uses, SREBP has now highly been regarded as a promising drug target for fatty liver diseases(22) and cancers,(23) which are characterized as having abnormal or increased lipid metabolism.(24−29) It has also been described that SREBP has a role in several disease-linked physiological processes not directly related to lipid homeostasis, including innate immunity(30) and virus infection.(31) One prominent class of synthetic SREBP inhibitors is fatostatin and its drug-like derivative FGH10019,(32,33) which have extensively been used as pharmacological tools for interrogating the roles of SREBP/SCAP in disease conditions.(34) None of these experimental SREBP inhibitors have yet reached clinical approval, and this lack of progress is partially due to the poor diversity of the SREBP inhibitors. We need a new seed molecule with distinct chemical scaffolds and pharmacological properties to increase our portfolio of synthetic SREBP inhibitors to meet the specific requirements of target disease conditions.
    The utility of 25(OH)D3 per se as a therapeutic agent is reduced by its VDR-mediated calcemic action, which is harmful above physiological concentrations. Synthetic vitamin D analogues selective for SREBP would provide a new set of SREBP inhibitors and represent a novel therapeutic application of vitamin D derivatives. Toward this goal, we previously reported the synthesis and biological evaluation of vitamin D3 analogues in which the C1 and/or C3 position(s) of the A-ring were substituted. Among them, compound 3 (Figure 1) selectively impaired SREBP/SCAP without eliciting VDR activity in cultured cells and permitted identification of one of the vitamin D-responsive genes, Soat1, as an SREBP-suppressed gene.(35) The discovery of compound 3 demonstrated that the SREBP effect of vitamin D is separable from its VDR activity. However, the utility of 3 in vivo was limited due to its residual calcemic activity at high doses and low bioavailability.
    To confront this problem, we here develop more drug-like, simplified vitamin D3 derivatives (5), in which the structure of the A-ring of 25(OH)D3 is completely replaced. Evaluation of the derivatives in cultured cells and mice led to the discovery of A-ring-substituted 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 derivatives as VDR-silent SREBP inhibitors and to the development of KK-052 (50), the first vitamin D-based SREBP inhibitor that has been demonstrated to mitigate hepatic lipid accumulation without calcemic action in mice.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis of Vitamin D3 Analogues with Pseudo A-Ring Structures

    During the course of screening our in-house collection of vitamin D analogues, we noted that 14-epi-previtamin D3 (4)(36) compromised the expression of an SREBP-responsive luciferase reporter(35) at a comparable level to 25(OH)D3 (data not shown). The 14-epi isomer of 25(OH)D3 has the tendency to isomerize via [1,7]-sigmatropic hydrogen shifts toward its previtamin form and has been demonstrated to display a lower affinity to VDR and markedly decreased calcemic action.(36a) This observation hinted that the 25-hydroxy CD-ring may be more critical than the A-ring for the SREBP inhibitory activity and that the entire hydroxylated A-ring, which is essential for the VDR activity, could be replaced by a functional group that occupies a similar volume to that of the A-ring, as represented by molecule 5 in Figure 1.
    In pursuit of this direction, we synthesized vitamin D3 analogues in which the A-ring is displaced by a suite of substituents (Figure 2). We took an advantage of a Grundmann’s ketone derivative 6 as a starting material, which is readily prepared from vitamin D3.(37) The smallest group introduced to 6 was exomethylene at C8 (steroidal numbering) in compound 10 (Figure 2). A subsequent two-step reaction of 6 afforded an allyl alcohol 8 (Scheme 1A),(38a) which allowed the introduction of a myriad of small, medium, and large substituents. These substituents include hydroxymethyl (11),(38b)tert-butylaminomethyl (12), and ethynyl (13) groups; cyclic and heterocyclic substituents (compounds 14–20 including carborane compound 17(39)); and decylamino (32) and decylsulfanyl (33) groups, respectively (Figure 2).
    To mimic the polarity and steric size of the natural A-ring, we also introduced a series of triazole and tetrazole derivatives to compound 8 through copper-catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition(40) or Mitsunobu reaction(41) (Scheme 1B,C). These triazole and tetrazole molecules are listed as compounds 21–31 in both medium and large substituent categories of Figure 2.

    SREBP/VDR Activities in Cultured Cells

    We first examined the ability of the newly synthesized 24 vitamin D3 derivatives (compounds 10–33) to inhibit the expression of an SREBP-responsive reporter gene in which the expression of luciferase was controlled by SREBP in CHO-K1 cells.(21,35) This assay was conducted at a single concentration of compound (5 μM) in a lipid-free medium, where 25(OH)D3 (1) was found to display substantial inhibitory activity. Compounds 10–13, which harbor relatively small substituents at the C7 position, were generally inactive (Figure 3). It is interesting in regards to ligand efficiency to note that the simple 8-exomethylene CD-ring 10 exhibited weak but detectable activity. In contrast, analogues with relatively bulky cyclic substituents (compounds 14–18 and 21–29) displayed SREBP inhibitory activities comparable to that of 25(OH)D3, although amides 19 and 20 had little effects. Interestingly, the inhibitory activity was decreased when more extended substituents were introduced (compounds 30–33) (Figure 3).
    The VDR activities of the same compounds were similarly assessed by using a VDR-responsive reporter gene in which the expression of luciferase is controlled by VDR.(21,35) The replacement of the 25(OH)D3 A-ring with the unnatural structures overall diminished the ability to stimulate VDR, most likely due to the lack of the two hydroxy groups critical for the VDR interaction (Figure 4). Although weakly, compounds 21, 22, 26, and 29 exhibited detectable VDR activity. The azole nitrogen of compounds 21, 22, and 26 and the hydroxy group of compound 29 may possibly mimic the hydroxy groups of 1α,25(OH)D3 that form hydrogen bonds with the ligand-binding pocket of VDR.(42) We excluded these VDR-active compounds.

    Introduction of Fluorine Atoms to Compounds 23–25

    Inspection of the data in Figures 3 and 4 prompted us to focus on the series of compounds 23–25, which displayed excellent selectivity to SREBP over VDR. However, as shown later in Figure 8, compounds 23–25 failed to exhibit clear SREBP inhibitory activity in vivo, probably due to their low bioavailability. A number of attempts have been made in the literature to increase metabolic stability of vitamin D analogues against CYP24A1, a primary deactivating enzyme of 25(OH)D3 and 1α,25(OH)2D3.(43−45) One notable approach used in the generation of clinically used vitamin D analogues is the introduction of fluorine atoms into the CD-ring side chain.(46) We used our improved fluorine built-in methods(47,48) (Schemes 2 and 3) to synthesize the fluorinated versions of compounds 23–25, each of which possesses a 26,26,26,27,27,27-hexafluoro(49) or 24,24-difluoro(50) CD-ring side chain (compounds 38, 40, and 41; and 46, 48, and 50, respectively) (Figure 5). The structure of the regio-isomers of tetrazolyl analogues were confirmed by both 1H and 13C NMR studies,(42) including NOESY experiments for 48 and 50 (see, Supporting Information). We also prepared their derivatives in which the para position of the benzene group is fluorinated (compounds 39, 47, 49, and 51). Evaluation of these fluorinated versions of compounds in cultured cells revealed that they all maintained SREBP inhibitory activities and lacked in VDR activity (Figures 6 and 7).

    Short-Term In Vivo Evaluation

    Many of the A-ring derivatives synthesized in the present study displayed selectivity toward SREBP over VDR almost equally well in cultured cells. The evaluation in cultured cells was not able to prioritize particular molecules for further investigations. To quickly and simultaneously examine their SREBP inhibitory activity and VDR-derived calcemic activity in vivo, we sought to establish a short-term in vivo screening system of mice. With reference to the previous report,(51) mice were fasted for 48 h then refed a special diet (low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet, lacking in vitamin D) for 48 h before sacrifice (Figure 8A). The expression levels of SREBP-responsive genes were significantly elevated in the livers after fasting and refeeding a special diet compared to the control mice with free access to a normal diet (Figure 8B).
    This system permitted the 4-day-long in vivo evaluation of 14 compounds (23–27, 38–41, 46, and 48–51), which exhibited excellent SREBP selectivity equally well in cultured cells. Figure 8A illustrates the protocol of the short-term in vivo evaluation: 10 mg/kg compounds or vehicle control were administered intraperitoneally once every 24 h during the fasting and refeeding. As expected, administration of the same amount of 25(OH)D3 markedly increased the serum calcium levels after 4 days, highlighting that the system is valid for estimating the in vivo calcemic effects of the test compounds (Figure 8D). Four fluorinated compounds (38, 39, 49, and 50) significantly suppressed the expression of two representative SREBP-response genes, ACC1 and FASN, compared to vehicle control; however, 38 and 39 also displayed the elevated levels of serum calcium, signifying that these compounds or their metabolites act on VDR in vivo under the test conditions (Figure 8C,D).
    These results encouraged us to reevaluate the effects of compounds 49 and 50, both of which mitigated the elevated expression of the three SREBP-responsive genes, ACC1, FASN, and SCD1, with no detectable increase of serum calcium levels. Repeated examination with the increased number of mice underscored that 50 (KK-052) significantly mitigated the elevated expression of the four SREBP-responsive genes in a reproducible fashion (Figure 8E). The expression levels of SCAP protein in the liver were increased after fasting and refeeding special diets. In accordance with the reported SCAP-degrading activity of 25(OH)D3, the increased hepatic expression of SCAP was canceled by treatment with 50 (KK-052) (Figure 8F). Thus, we prioritize 50 (KK-052) for further investigations.

    In Vitro Evaluation of KK-052 (50)

    We set out to verify the effects of KK-052 (50) on SREBP and SCAP by gene reporter assay and western blot analysis. Similar to the results of our previous screening, KK-052 inhibited the activation of the reporter gene in a concentration-dependent manner comparable to 25(OH)D3 (Figure 9A). Nonlinear regression analysis showed the sigmoidal dose–response with similar IC50 values for KK-052 and 25(OH)D3 (0.7227 and 1.176 μM, respectively). The IC50 values for two close analogues of KK-052, compounds 49 and 51, were also determined to be 1.16 and 1.60 μM, respectively (Figure S1A). These values are comparable to or better than the IC50 values of FGH10019 (0.7 μM) and fatostatin (∼5 μM) that were previously measured using the identical assay protocol.(32,33) KK-052 (50), 49, and 51 displayed no detectable cytotoxicity in CHO cells as evaluated by the expression of a cotransfected β-galactosidase gene (Figure S1B).
    The SREBP inhibitory activity of KK-052 was attributable to its ability in decreasing the level of endogenous SREBP and SCAP similar to the actions of 25(OH)D3(21) although the effect was less evident at 1 μM concentration (Figure 9B). Western blot analysis using CHO-K1 cells expressing FLAG-tagged SCAP more clearly showed the SCAP depletion by KK-052 (Figure 9C). The decreased SCAP level was restored by adding MG132, a proteasome inhibitor, suggesting that KK-052 induces proteasomal degradation of SCAP just as 25(OH)D3 (Figure S2). Although SCAP is the most likely target of KK-052 in light of the proposed mechanism of 25(OH)D3, the direct binding target of KK-052 remains unclear. Overall, our results were consistent with the effects of KK-052 in vivo.

    Efficacy and Safety of KK-052 (50) for the Treatment of Fatty Liver

    To analyze the long-term efficacy and safety of KK-052 (50) for the treatment of fatty liver, we used leptin-deficient ob/ob mice that spontaneously exhibit fatty liver whose development depends on SREBP-mediated de novo lipogenesis.(52) Six-week-old ob/ob mice were treated with 10 mg/kg KK-052, 10 mg/kg 25(OH)D3, or vehicle control five times per week for 4 weeks (Figure 10A). All ob/ob mice treated with 25(OH)D3 became sick due to hypercalcemia and euthanized at 1 week, while ob/ob mice treated with KK-052 appeared healthy until the end of the experiments. Treatment with KK-052 slightly but significantly decreased weight gain in ob/ob mice (Figure 10B). Histology of the liver of vehicle-treated ob/ob mice revealed marked liver steatosis, and such conditions were attenuated by treatment with KK-052 (Figure 10C). Moreover, hepatic triglyceride (TG) and cholesterol contents were significantly decreased in the KK-052-treated ob/ob mice compared to the vehicle-treated ob/ob mice (Figure 10D). Importantly, the treatment with KK-052 significantly decreased serum levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a marker of liver damage, as well as TG and glucose (Figure 10E). There was no detectable difference in the serum calcium levels between KK-052- and vehicle-treated group. Taken together, KK-052 mitigates fatty liver development without inducing hypercalcemia in ob/ob mice.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In the present study, substitution of the A-ring of 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 with a completely unnatural entity led to the discovery of VDR-silent SREBP inhibitors and to the development of KK-052 (50). KK-052 represents the first vitamin D-based SREBP inhibitor that has been demonstrated to mitigate hepatic lipid accumulation without calcemic action in mice. Further studies will be required for the clinical application of KK-052. Nonetheless, its efficacy and safety profile suggests that KK-052 or its analogues may prove to be useful in the treatment of SREBP-linked disorders including fatty liver diseases.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General

    1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on JEOL AL-400 NMR (400 MHz) and ECP-600 NMR (600 MHz) spectrometers. 1H NMR spectra were referenced with (CH3)4Si (δ 0.00 ppm) as an internal standard. 13C NMR spectra were referenced with deuterated solvents (δ 77.0 ppm for CDCl3 and 49.3 ppm for CD3OD). IR spectra were recorded on the JASCO FT-IR-800 Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer. High-resolution mass spectra were obtained on a SHIMADZU LCMS-IT-TOF mass spectrometer with electrospray ionization (ESI) methods. Optical rotations were measured on a JASCO DIP-370 digital polarimeter. Column chromatography was performed on silica gel 60N (Kanto Chemical Co., Inc., 100–210 μm) or silica gel 60 (Merck, 0.040–0.063 mm). Preparative thin-layer chromatography was performed on silica gel 60 F254 (Merck, 0.5 mm). All experiments were performed under anhydrous conditions and an argon atmosphere unless otherwise stated.
    The purities of the compounds tested in animal studies, 23–27, 38–41, 46, and 48–51, were satisfied more than 95%, confirmed by reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis (YMC-Pack ODS-A column, 150 × 4.6 mm, 1.0 mL/min, CH3CN/H2O = 80/20) and normal-phase HPLC analysis (CHIRALCEL OD-H column, 250 × 4.6 mm, 1.0 mL/min, CH3CN only) for compound 50 (KK-052); see, charts in the Supporting Information.

    ({(R)-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-(2-Azidoethylidene)-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]-2-methylheptan-2-yl}oxy)triethylsilane (9)

    To the solution of 8(38a) (300.0 mg, 0.71 mmol) and pyridine (337.0 mg, 344 μL, 4.26 mmol) in CCl4 (30 mL) was added tri-n-butylphosphine (574.6 mg, 700 μL, 2.84 mmol) at 0 °C, over 5 min, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 15 min. After the reaction was diluted with hexane (50 mL), the mixture was filtered and concentrated. The obtained crude allylchloride was used for the next reaction without further purification. To the solution of the above crude allylchloride in dimethylformamide (DMF) (15 mL) was added NaN3 (138.5 mg, 2.13 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 20 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 30:1) to obtain 9 (273.1 mg, 86%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    9: [α]D27 +36.6 (c 1.61, CHCl3); IR (neat): 2095, 1380, 1235, 1045, 743 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.57 (q, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 0.59 (s, 1H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 0.95 (t, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 0.99–1.06 (m, 1H), 1.19–1.55 (m, 20H), 1.67–1.71 (m, 2H), 1.86–1.94 (m, 1H), 2.00–2.05 (m, 2H), 2.60–2.62 (m, 1H), 3.73 (dd, J = 6.6, 13.2 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (dd, J = 7.8, 13.8 Hz, 1H), 5.13 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 6.9, 7.2, 11.9, 18.9, 20.9, 22.2, 23.9, 27.6, 28.9, 29.9, 30.1, 36.2, 36.5, 40.4, 45.2, 45.6, 47.5, 55.9, 56.7, 73.5, 112.7, 147.2; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C26H49N3OSi [M + Na]+, 470.3537; found, 470.3577.

    (R)-2-Methyl-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR)-7a-methyl-4-methyleneoctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]heptan-2-ol (10)

    To the suspension of the methyltriphenylphosphonium bromide (90.5 mg, 0.253 mmol) in tetrahydrofuran (THF) (2 mL) was added n-BuLi (146 μL, 1.65 M in hexane, 0.241 mmol) at −78 °C and stirred at the same temperature for 15 min and 0 °C for 20 min. To the mixture was added the 8-keto CD ring (6)(37) (50.0 mg, 0.127 mmol) in THF (2 mL) and stirred at the same temperature for 1 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at 0 °C, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc twice, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained residue was used for the next reaction without further purification. Tetrabutylammonium fluoride (381 μL, 1 M in THF, 0.381 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude residue in THF (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 5:1) to obtain 10 (9.6 mg, 27%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    10: [α]D27 +63.5 (c 0.75, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3360, 1649, 1469, 1378, 1148, 885 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.56 (s, 3H), 0.94 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 1.02–1.09 (m, 1H), 1.21–1.64 (m, 1H), 1.84–2.01 (m, 4H), 2.26 (dd, J = 4.1, 13.3 Hz, 1H), 4.46 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.72 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.7, 18.8, 20.8, 22.2, 23.7, 27.7, 29.2, 29.4, 35.4, 36.1, 36.4, 40.2, 44.4, 45.1, 55.3, 56.3, 71.1, 105.0, 149.6; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C19H33 [M – OH]+, 261.2577; found, 261.2577.

    (R)-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-(2-Hydroxyethylidene)-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]-2-methylheptan-2-ol (11)(38b)

    Tetrabutylammonium fluoride (106 μL, 1 M THF solution, 0.106 mmol) was added to the solution of 8(38a) (30.5 mg, 0.072 mmol) in THF (4 mL), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 51 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 2:1) to obtain 11 (11.7 mg, 53%, SM recovery 37%) as colorless oil.
    11: [α]D27 +82.7 (c 2.48, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3327, 1468, 1375, 1004, 647 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.55 (s, 3H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H), 1.02–1.08 (m, 1H), 1.21–1.54 (m, 20H), 1.64–1.67 (m, 2H), 1.82–2.01 (m, 3H), 2.61–2.64 (m, 1H), 4.17–4.23 (m, 2H), 5.21 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.8, 18.8, 20.8, 22.2, 23.5, 27.6, 28.7, 29.2, 29.3, 36.0, 36.4, 40.3, 44.4, 45.3, 55.6, 56.5, 58.7, 71.1, 119.2, 143.8; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C20H36O2Na [M + Na]+, 331.2608; found, 331.2584.

    (R)-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-[2-(tert-Butylamino)ethylidene]-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}-2-methylheptan-2-ol (12)

    PDC (127.9 mg, 0.34 mmol) was added to the solution of 8(38a) (99.5 mg, 0.225 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (4 mL) and DMF (0.5 mL) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature under air for 2 h. The solution was diluted with Et2O, filtered through a celite pad, and concentrated. To the solution of the obtained crude aldehyde above and tert-butylamine (99.4 mg, 143 μL, 1.36 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added anhydrous MgSO4 (1 g) at room temperature under air. The mixture was stirred for 70 min and refluxed overnight. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude imine was used for the next reaction without further purification. To the solution of the above crude imine in MeOH (3 mL) was added NaBH4 (5.1 mg, 0.136 mmol) at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at the same temperature under air for 1 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude amine was used for the next reaction without further purification. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (129.3 mg, 0.68 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude amine in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 20 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2 three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was diluted with MeOH (3 mL) and 1 M aqueous NaOH (3 mL) and stirred for 10 min. To the mixture was added H2O, and extracted with CH2Cl2 four times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (EtOAc only 1% Et3N) to obtain 12 (76.2 mg, 93%, 4 steps) as colorless oil.
    12: [α]D27 +63.0 (c 0.44, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3365, 1470, 1377, 1363, 1215 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.54 (s, 3H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 0.98–2.00 (m, 35H), 2.55–2.59 (m, 1H), 3.21–3.30 (m, 2H), 5.08 (t, J = 6.7 Hz, 1H), 6.62–6.64 (m, 2H), 6.69–6.72 (m, 1H), 7.15–7.20 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.9, 18.8, 20.8, 22.2, 23.4, 27.7, 28.7, 28.8, 29.2, 29.3, 36.1, 36.4, 39.4, 40.4, 44.4, 45.2, 50.8, 55.7, 56.5, 71.1, 118.6, 141.5; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C24H46ON [M + H]+, 364.3574; found, 364.3603.

    (R)-2-Methyl-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-4-(prop-2-yn-1-ylidene)octahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]heptan-2-ol (13)

    To the solution of 8(38a) (522.4 mg, 1.24 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) were added 4-methylmorpholine N-oxide (290.5 mg, 2.48 mmol) and 4 Å molecular sieves (100 mg), cooled to 0 °C. To the mixture was added tetrapropylammonium perruthenate (TPAP) (130.3 mg, 0.37 mmol) and stirred at 0 °C for 1 h. The reaction was diluted with an excess amount of Et2O. The mixture was filtered with celite and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 10:1) to obtain the crude aldehyde (439.2 mg), and this was used for the next reaction without further purification. To the solution of the trimethylsilyl diazomethane (71 μL, 2.0 M in diethylether, 0.143 mmol) in THF (2 mL) was added n-BuLi (82 μL, 1.65 M in hexane, 0.135 mmol) at −78 °C and stirred at the same temperature for 15 min. To the mixture was added the crude CD aldehyde above (30 mg) in THF (2 mL) and stirred at the same temperature for 30 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at −78 °C, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc twice, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 50:1) to obtain the crude CD-alkyne (22.2 mg). p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (27.0 mg, 0.142 mmol) was added to a solution of the crude CD-alkyne (30.0 mg) in MeOH (3 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 10 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified on a preparative silica gel thin-layer chromatography (TLC) plate (hexane/EtOAc = 4:1) to obtain 13 (19.7 mg, 58% 3 steps) as colorless oil.
    13: [α]D27 +147.1 (c 1.52, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3381, 3310, 2360, 2341, 1627, 1470, 1378, 1214, 1149, 911, 735 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.55 (s, 3H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 3H), 1.02–1.08 (m, 1H), 1.18–1.63 (m, 17H), 1.67–1.72 (m, 1H), 1.75–1.80 (m, 1H), 1.84–1.93 (m, 1H), 2.00–2.04 (m, 1H), 2.96–2.99 (m, 2H), 5.05–5.06 (m, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.9, 18.7, 20.8, 21.9, 23.3, 27.6, 29.2, 29.4, 31.4, 36.0, 36.3, 40.0, 44.4, 46.3, 55.7, 56.4, 71.1, 79.3, 81.6, 99.3, 157.9; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C21H32 [M – OH]+, 285.2577; found, 285.2571.

    3-Deoxy-25-hydroxy-19-norvitamin D3 (14)

    LHMDS (332 μL, 1.0 M THF solution, 0.332 mmol) was added to the solution of CD-ring sulfone, 2-({2-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-1-{(R)-6-methyl-6-[(triethylsilyl)oxy]heptan-2-yl}octahydro-4H-inden-4-ylidene]ethyl}sulfonyl)benzo[d]thiazole,(38a) (99.1 mg, 0.164 mmol) in THF (2 mL) at −78 °C. After stirring for 30 min, the solution of cyclohexanone (48.8 mg, 50 μL, 0.497 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture, and the mixture was stirred at −78 °C for 30 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O at the same temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane only) to obtain the crude coupling product (41.5 mg), and it was used for the next reaction without further purification. Tetrabutylammonium fluoride (497 μL, 1 M THF solution, 0.497 mmol) was added to the solution of the above crude coupling product (41.5 mg) in THF (5 mL), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 5:1) to obtain 14 (30.9 mg, 50%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    14: [α]D27 +64.3 (c 2.06, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3368, 1445, 1376, 1215, 1148, 863, 759 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.55 (s, 3H), 0.94 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H), 1.03–1.08 (m, 1H), 1.20–1.67 (m, 23H), 1.86–1.92 (m, 1H), 1.97–2.01 (m, 2H), 2.13–2.24 (m, 3H), 2.33–2.35 (m, 1H), 2.78–2.82 (m, 1H), 5.84 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H), 6.06 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.1, 18.8, 20.8, 22.3, 23.4, 26.9, 27.6, 27.7, 28.6, 28.7, 28.9, 29.2, 29.3, 36.1, 36.4, 37.6, 40.6, 44.4, 45.6, 56.3, 56.5, 71.1, 115.7, 117.3, 140.4, 140.6; HRMS (ESI–): calcd for C26H43O [M – H]−, 371.3308; found, 371.3310.

    (R)-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-[2-(Benzo[d]thiazol-2-ylthio)ethylidene]-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}-2-methylheptan-2-ol (15)

    To a solution of 2-mercaptobenzothiazole (29.7 mg, 0.178 mmol), Ph3P (29.9 mg, 0.114 mmol), and 8(38a) (30.7 mg, 0.073 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) was added diisopropyl azodicarboxylate (60 μL, 1.9 M in toluene, 0.114 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 2 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O at 0 °C, the mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2 three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was roughly purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 10:1) to obtain the crude sulfide. Tetrabutylammonium fluoride (111 μL, 1 M in THF, 0.111 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude sulfide in THF (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 21 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified on a preparative silica gel TLC plate (hexane/EtOAc = 5:1) to obtain 15 (16.1 mg, 50%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    15: [α]D27 +77.3 (c 1.24, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3390, 1457, 1427, 1377, 1238, 996, 756 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.49 (s, 3H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 1.00–1.08 (m, 1H), 1.21–1.73 (m, 21H), 1.81–2.00 (m, 3H), 1.81–2.00 (m, 3H), 2.74–2.78 (m, 1H), 4.02 (dd, J = 7.1, 12.4 Hz, 1H), 4.13 (dd, J = 7.8, 12.8 Hz, 1H), 5.20 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.28 (td, J = 1.4, 8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.41 (td, J = 1.4, 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.75 (dd, J = 1.4, 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.86 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.7, 18.8, 20.8, 22.1, 23.5, 27.6, 28.8, 29.2, 29.3, 31.3, 36.0, 36.3, 40.3, 44.4, 45.6, 55.7, 56.4, 71.1, 113.1, 120.9, 121.4, 124.1, 126.0, 135.2, 146.1, 153.3, 167.2; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C27H40NOS2 [M + H]+, 458.2546; found, 458.2578.

    2-(2-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-1-[(R)-6-Hydroxy-6-methylheptan-2-yl]-7a-methyloctahydro-4H-inden-4-ylidene}ethyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (16)

    To a solution of phthalimide (69.6 mg, 0.473 mmol), Ph3P (29.9 mg, 0.473 mmol), and 8(38a) (100.0 mg, 0.237 mmol) in THF (5 mL) was added diisopropyl azodicarboxylate (249 μL, 1.9 M in toluene, 0.473 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at the room temperature for 10 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was roughly purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 6:1) to obtain the crude phthalimide product. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (113.1 mg, 0.595 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude phthalimide in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min under air. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (EtOAc only) to obtain 16 (57.8 mg, 56% 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    16: [α]D27 +44.7 (c 0.98, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3394, 1715, 1394, 1088, 941, 724 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.49 (s, 3H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H), 0.99–1.05 (m, 1H), 1.17–1.64 (m, 19H), 1.66–1.71 (m, 2H), 1.80–1.86 (m, 1H), 1.92 (t, J = 9.6 Hz, 1H), 1.92 (dt, J = 3.0, 11.4 Hz, 1H), 2.91–2.95 (m, 1H), 4.27–4.37 (m, 2H), 5.20 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 7.67–7.70 (m, H), 7.81–7.84 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.8, 18.8, 20.8, 22.1, 23.4, 27.6, 28.8, 29.2, 29.3, 35.1, 36.0, 36.3, 40.3, 44.4, 45.4, 55.6, 56.4, 71.1, 113.7, 123.1, 132.3, 133.7, 144.5, 168.1; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C28H39NO3Na [M + Na]+, 460.2822; found, 460.2850.

    (R)-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-(ortho-Carboranylmethylidene)-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]-2-methylheptan-2-ol (17)

    To the solution of 8(38a) (522.4 mg, 1.24 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) were added 4-methylmorpholine N-oxide (290.5 mg, 2.48 mmol) and 4 Å molecular sieves (100 mg), cooled to 0 °C. To the mixture was added TPAP (130.3 mg, 0.37 mmol) and stirred at 0 °C for 1 h. The reaction was diluted with an excess amount of Et2O. The mixture was filtered with celite and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 10:1) to obtain the crude aldehyde (439.2 mg), and this was used for the next reaction without further purification. To the solution of the trimethylsilyl diazomethane (71 μL, 2.0 M in diethylether, 0.143 mmol) in THF (2 mL) was added n-BuLi (82 μL, 1.65 M in hexane, 0.135 mmol) at −78 °C and stirred at the same temperature for 15 min. To the mixture was added the crude CD aldehyde above (30 mg) in THF (2 mL) and stirred at the same temperature for 30 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at −78 °C, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc twice, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 50:1) to obtain the crude CD-alkyne (22.2 mg).
    To a solution of N,N-dimethylaniline (93.2 mg, 97 μL, 0.769 mmol) and the above crude CD-alkyne (51.1 mg) in toluene (5 mL) was added B10H14 (43.3 mg, 0.356 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at 100 °C for 15 min. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane only—hexane/EtOAc = 20:1) and followed by purification by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 100:1) to obtain the crude product (20.0 mg). p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (14.1 mg, 0.074 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude product in MeOH (3 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min under air. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 5:1) to obtain 17 (13.1 mg, 16%, 4 steps) as colorless oil.
    17: [α]D27 +117.4 (c 1.01, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3463, 2602, 2565, 1467, 1440, 1376, 1208, 1128, 1072, 1020, 931, 721 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.50 (s, 3H), 0.55–0.62 (m, 1H), 0.92–2.82 (m, 38H), 3.20 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 3H), 3.64 (br s, 1H), 5.09 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.7, 18.8, 20.7, 22.1, 23.4, 27.3, 29.0, 29.4, 35.9, 36.3, 40.0, 44.3, 46.8, 56.3, 56.6, 62.8, 71.0, 74.0, 114.9, 150.3; HRMS (ESI–): calcd for C21H43OB10 [M – H]−, 421.4282; found, 421.4321.

    (R)-2-Methyl-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-4-[2-(phenylamino)ethylidene]octahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}heptan-2-ol (18)

    PDC (333.8 mg, 0.887 mmol) was added to the solution of 8(38a) (151.7 mg, 0.359 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (6 mL) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature under air for 3 h. The solution was diluted with Et2O, filtered through a celite pad, and concentrated to obtain the crude aldehyde. To the solution of the above crude aldehyde and aniline (330.6 mg, 324 μL, 3.55 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) was added anhydrous MgSO4 (1 g) at room temperature under air. The mixture was stirred for 90 min and refluxed for 40 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2 three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude imine was used for the next reaction without further purification. To the solution of the above crude imine in MeOH (10 mL) was added NaBH4 (40.2 mg, 1.07 mmol) at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at the same temperature under air for 30 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude amine was used for the next reaction without further purification. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (2.7 g, 14.2 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude amine in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 45 min. After that, the reaction was quenched with 1 M aqueous NaOH solution and stirred for a further 10 min. The mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2 three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 10:1–3:1) to obtain 18 (88.6 mg, 65% 4 steps) as colorless oil.
    18: [α]D27 +67.9 (c 1.89, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3368, 1603, 1505, 1469, 1377, 1318, 1248, 1216, 1151, 755, 692 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.56 (s, 3H), 0.95 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 1.03–1.10 (m, 1H), 1.18–1.72 (m, 22H), 1.84–2.06 (m, 3H), 2.65–2.69 (m, 1H), 3.71–3.81 (m, 2H), 5.01 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 6.62–6.64 (m, 2H), 6.69–6.72 (m, 1H), 7.15–7.20 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.8, 18.8, 20.8, 22.2, 23.4, 27.6, 28.8, 29.2, 29.3, 36.1, 36.4, 40.3, 41.3, 45.2, 55.6, 56.5, 71.1, 113.0, 117.1, 117.3, 129.1, 143.0, 148.4; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C26H42ON [M + H]+, 384.3261; found, 384.3258.

    2-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-1-[(R)-6-Hydroxy-6-methylheptan-2-yl]-7a-methyloctahydro-4H-inden-4-ylidene}-1-(piperidin-1-yl)ethan-1-one (19)

    PDC (127.9 mg, 0.34 mmol) was added to the solution of 8(38a) (103.9 mg, 0.246 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (4 mL) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature under air for 3 h. The solution was diluted with Et2O, filtered with celite, and concentrated to obtain the crude aldehyde. To the mixture of the above crude aldehyde, NaH2PO4 (74.3 mg, 0.476 mmol), 30% H2O2 (72 μL) in H2O (1 mL), and t-BuOH (3 mL) was added NaClO2 (24.6 mg, 0.272 mmol) at 0 °C under air and stirred at the same temperature for 5 min and at room temperature for 4 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 2:1) to obtain 2-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-1-{(R)-6-methyl-6-[(triethylsilyl)oxy]heptan-2-yl}octahydro-4H-inden-4-ylidene]acetic acid (A) (82.5 mg, 80%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    A: [α]D27 +93.9 (c 1.54, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3048, 1686, 1638, 1459, 1416, 1268, 1212, 1045, 735 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.58 (s, 3H), 0.56 (q, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 0.92–0.99 (m, 13H), 1.19–1.77 (m, 19H), 1.84–1.96 (m, 1H), 2.01–2.04 (m, 1H), 2.10–2.15 (m, 1H), 3.82–3.88 (m, 1H), 5.49 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 6.8, 7.1, 12.0, 18.7, 20.8, 22.1, 24.0, 27.4, 29.8, 29.9, 30.0, 35.9, 36.3, 40.1, 45.5, 47.4, 56.8, 57.1, 73.4, 111.3, 166.6, 172.0; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C28H46O3SiNa [M + Na]+, 481.3108; found, 481.3065.
    To a solution of piperidine (24.1 mg, 28 μL, 0.283 mmol) and carboxylic acid (A) obtained above (82.5 mg, 0.189 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) were added diisopropylethylamine (61.0 mg, 82 μL, 0.472 mmol) and the BOP reagent (166.8 mg, 0.377 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated to obtain the crude amide. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (179.4 mg, 0.943 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude amide in MeOH (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min under air. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 2:1–1:1) to obtain 19 (57.3 mg, 73%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    19: [α]D27 +84.8 (c 0.96, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3374, 1610, 1444, 1255, 753 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.59 (s, 3H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 1.01–1.11 (m, 1H), 1.20–2.03 (m, 30H), 2.72–2.77 (m, 1H), 3.46–3.51 (m, 3H), 3.61 (br s, 1H), 5.51 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.1, 18.7, 20.7, 22.1, 23.3, 24.6, 25.8, 26.4, 27.5, 29.2, 29.3, 30.5, 36.0, 36.3, 40.0, 42.2, 44.3, 46.1, 47.5, 55.6, 56.4, 71.0, 114.8, 149.8, 167.7; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C25H44NO2 [M + H]+, 390.3367; found, 390.3391.

    2-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-1-[(R)-6-Hydroxy-6-methylheptan-2-yl]-7a-methyloctahydro-4H-inden-4-ylidene}-1-morpholinoethan-1-one (20)

    To a solution of morpholine (32.0 mg, 32 μL, 0.367 mmol) and carboxylic acid (A) (80.2 mg, 0.184 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) were added diisopropylethylamine (80 μL, 0.46 mmol) and the BOP reagent (162.4 mg, 0.367 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 21 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NH4Cl at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated to obtain the crude amide. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (175.0 mg, 0.92 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude amide in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min under air. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 1:1) to obtain 20 (65.4 mg, 91%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    20: [α]D27 +91.8 (c 1.14, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3426, 1615, 1463, 1231, 1117, 851, 753 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.59 (s, 3H), 0.94 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 3H), 1.03–1.11 (m, 1H), 1.21–1.62 (m, 19H), 1.69–1.71 (m, 1H), 1.76–1.81 (m, 1H), 1.88–1.92 (m, 1H), 2.01–2.06 (m, 2H), 2.83–2.85 (m, 1H), 3.52 (br s, 1H), 3.65–3.69 (m, 6H), 5.51 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.1, 18.7, 20.7, 22.1, 23.4, 27.4, 29.2, 29.4, 30.6, 36.0, 36.3, 39.9, 41.7, 44.3, 46.3, 46.9, 55.8, 56.4, 66.9, 71.0, 113.6, 152.3, 167.9; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C24H41NO3Na [M + Na]+, 414.2979; found, 414.2998.

    (R)-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-[2-(1H-Tetrazol-1-yl)ethylidene]-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}-2-methylheptan-2-ol (21) and (R)-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-[2-(2H-tetrazol-2-yl)ethylidene]-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}-2-methylheptan-2-ol (22)

    To a solution of 1H-tetrazole (45.4 mg, 0.649 mmol), Ph3P (206.4 mg, 9.72 mmol), and 11 (100 mg, 0.324 mmol) in THF (5 mL) was added diisopropyl azodicarboxylate (512 μL, 1.9 M in toluene, 9.72 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O at 0 °C, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 2:1—EtOAc only) to obtain the less-polar product 22 (43.2 mg, 37%) and the more-polar product 21 (38.8 mg, 33%) each as colorless oil.
    21: [α]D27 +64.5 (c 0.62, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3400, 1468, 1445, 1376, 1162, 1101, 912, 734, 661 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.55 (s, 3H), 0.94 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 1.01–1.09 (m, 1H), 1.20–1.61 (m, 18H), 1.72–1.82 (m, 2H), 1.86–1.94 (m, 1H), 2.01–2.08 (m, 3H), 2.65–2.70 (m, 1H), 5.03–5.12 (m, 1H), 5.23 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 8.53 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.9, 18.8, 20.8, 22.1, 23.3, 27.5, 28.9, 29.2, 29.4, 36.0, 36.3, 40.0, 44.3, 45.3, 45.8, 55.6, 56.4, 71.1, 110.9, 151.8, 149.4; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C21H36N4ONa [M + Na]+, 383.2781; found, 383.2789.
    22: [α]D27 +53.6 (c 1.31, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3427, 1468, 1454, 1376, 1282, 1027, 911, 736 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.50 (s, 3H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H), 1.01–1.06 (m, 1H), 1.20–2.02 (m, 24H), 2.77–2.80 (m, 1H), 5.23–5.32 (m, 3H), 8.47 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.8, 18.8, 20.8, 22.0, 23.3, 27.5, 28.0, 29.2, 29.4, 36.0, 36.3, 40.1, 44.3, 45.8, 50.1, 55.6, 56.4, 71.0, 111.4, 148.1, 152.8; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C21H36N4ONa [M + Na]+, 383.2781; found, 383.2793.

    (R)-2-Methyl-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-4-[2-(5-phenyl-2H-tetrazol-2-yl)ethylidene]octahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}heptan-2-ol (23) and (R)-2-methyl-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-4-[2-(5-phenyl-1H-tetrazol-1-yl)ethylidene]octahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}heptan-2-ol (24)

    To a solution of 5-phenyl-1H-tetrazole (311.3 mg, 2.13 mmol), Ph3P (372.5 mg, 1.42 mmol), and 8(38a) (305.3 mg, 0.722 mmol) in THF (10 mL) was added diisopropyl azodicarboxylate (1.12 mL, 1.9 M in toluene, 2.13 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 3 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O at 0 °C, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was roughly purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 3:1) to obtain the crude products (less-polar and more-polar products). p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (285.3 mg, 1.50 mmol) was added to a solution of the above less-polar crude product in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 40 min under air. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 1:1) to obtain 23 (187.8 mg, 60%) as colorless oil.
    23: [α]D27 +41.2 (c 1.33, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3419, 1467, 1450, 1378, 1216, 761, 694 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.54 (s, 3H), 0.94 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 1.00–1.10 (m, 1H), 1.19–2.05 (m, 24H), 2.83–2.86 (m, 1H), 5.29–5.36 (m, 3H), 7.43–7.52 (m, 3H), 8.12–8.15 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.8, 18.8, 20.8, 22.0, 23.4, 27.6, 29.1, 29.2, 29.4, 36.0, 36.3, 40.2, 44.4, 45.9, 50.2, 55.7, 56.5, 71.1, 111.6, 126.8, 127.6, 128.8, 130.1, 148.0, 165.0; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C27H40N4ONa [M + Na]+, 459.3094; found, 459.3079.
    p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (190.2 mg, 1.0 mmol) was added to a solution of the above more-polar crude product in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 40 min under air. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified on a preparative silica gel TLC plate (hexane/EtOAc = 1:1) to obtain 24 (48.4 mg, 15%) as colorless oil.
    24: [α]D27 +67.2 (c 0.09, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3425, 1471, 1377, 1219, 758, 698 cm–1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.46 (s, 3H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H), 1.00–1.07 (m, 1H), 1.21–1.72 (m, 21H), 1.82–2.01 (m, 3H), 2.51–2.56 (m, 1H), 5.07–5.17 (m, 3H), 7.52–7.60 (m, 3H), 7.68–7.71 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.8, 18.8, 20.8, 22.1, 23.1, 27.5, 28.9, 29.2, 29.4, 36.0, 36.3, 40.0, 44.3, 45.6, 45.7, 55.52, 56.4, 71.1, 112.9, 124.2, 128.8, 129.1, 131.1, 146.5, 154.1; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C27H40N4ONa [M + Na]+, 459.3094; found, 459.3093.

    (R)-2-Methyl-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-4-[2-(4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)ethylidene]octahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}heptan-2-ol (25)

    To a solution of phenylacetylene (56.9 mg, 24 μL, 0.557 mmol), diisopropylethylamine (719.9 mg, 0.97 mL, 5.57 mmol), and 9 (50.3 mg, 0.112 mmol) in THF (4 mL) was added CuI (21.2 mg, 0.557 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 68 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude triazole product was used for the next reaction without further purification. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (106.0 mg, 0.557 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude triazole in MeOH (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 15 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 2:1) to obtain 25 (12.1 mg, 25%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
    25: [α]D27 +50.5 (c 0.29, CHCl3); IR (neat): 3393, 1468, 1378, 1223, 766, 695 cm–1; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.58 (s, 3H), 0.95 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 3H), 1.03–1.11 (m, 1H), 1.21–1.61 (m, 20H), 1.74–1.81 (m, 2H), 1.87–1.94 (m, 1H), 2.01–2.06 (m, 2H), 2.73–2.75 (m, 1H), 5.04–5.10 (m, 2H), 5.27 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.31–7.33 (m, 1H), 7.42 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 7.70 (s, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 11.9, 18.8, 20.8, 22.1, 23.4, 27.5, 28.9, 29.2, 29.4, 36.0, 36.3, 40.1, 44.4, 45.7, 47.2, 55.7, 56.5, 71.1, 112.8, 118.9, 125.7, 128.0, 128.8, 130.8, 147.3, 147.8; HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C28H41N3O [M + H]+, 436.3322; found, 436.3312.

    (R)-2-Methyl-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-4-{2-[4-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl]ethylidene}octahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]heptan-2-ol (26)

    To a mixture of 2-ethynylpyridine (38.6 mg, 38 μL, 0.374 mmol), sodium l-ascorbate (38.3 mg, 0.193 mmol), 2,6-lutidine (39.0 mg, 43 μL, 0.364 mmol), and 9 (83.8 mg, 0.187 mmol) in t-BuOH (3 mL), and H2O (3 mL) was added CuSO4·5H2O (5.2 mg, 0.021 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 24 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude triazole product was used for the next reaction without further purification. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (182.8 mg, 0.961 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude triazole in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 20 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 1:1) to obtain 26 (60.3 mg, 74%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.

    (R)-2-Methyl-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-7a-methyl-4-{2-[4-(thiophen-2-yl)-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl]ethylidene}octahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]heptan-2-ol (27)

    To a mixture of 2-ethynylthiophene (39.4 mg, 36 μL, 0.364 mmol), sodium l-ascorbate (37.8 mg, 0.191 mmol), 2,6-lutidine (39.0 mg, 42 μL, 0.364 mmol), and 9 (81.6 mg, 0.182 mmol) in t-BuOH (3 mL) and H2O (3 mL) was added CuSO4·5H2O (4.2 mg, 0.017 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 22 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude triazole product was used for the next reaction without further purification. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (179.2 mg, 0.942 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude triazole in MeOH (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 20 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 2:1) to obtain 27 (53.5 mg, 67%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.

    (R)-6-{(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-[2-(4-Butyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)ethylidene]-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl}-2-methylheptan-2-ol (28)

    To a solution of 1-hexyne (9.9 mg, 13.8 μL, 0.12 mmol), diisopropylethylamine (719.9 mg, 0.97 mL, 5.57 mmol), and 9 (53.8 mg, 0.112 mmol) in THF (4 mL) was added CuI (106.1 mg, 0.557 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 112 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude triazole product was used for the next reaction without further purification. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (106.0 mg, 0.557 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude triazole in MeOH (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 20 min. After the reaction was quenched with H2O and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 at room temperature, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc = 2:1–1:1) to obtain 28 (15.6 mg, 31%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.

    (R)-6-[(1R,3aS,7aR,E)-4-{2-[4-(4-Hydroxybutyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl]ethylidene}-7a-methyloctahydro-1H-inden-1-yl]-2-methylheptan-2-ol (29)

    To a solution of 5-hexyn-1-ol (108.9 mg, 120 μL, 1.11 mmol), diisopropylethylamine (1.44 g, 1.94 mL, 11.14 mmol), and 9 (60 mg, 0.124 mmol) in THF (8 mL) was added CuI (212.2 mg, 1.11 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 118 h. After the reaction was quenched with H2O, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc three times, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The obtained crude triazole product was used for the next reaction without further purification. p-Toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (216.0 mg, 1.11 mmol) was added to a solution of the above crude triazole in MeOH (20 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature under air for 25 min. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (EtOAc only) to obtain 29 (19.2 mg, 20%, 2 steps) as colorless oil.
